pullRequest.title: New sample: Configure subnetwork trace
pullRequest.bodyText:
Hi both,
I've finally come around to finishing this sample.
It's a fairly complex one, so I imagine there's still a lot of room for improvement. Take your time as it's also a big one! Hopefully there aren't too many inconsistencies, but apologies if I missed out anything regarding the readme/metadata/screenshot.
If you two have any suggestions about refactoring/increasing readibility, I'll gladly apply them. So if you have any ideas for improving convertToDataType() and expressionToString() that would also be great.
Other than that, limiting the input in comparisonValuesTextField to numerical perhaps isn't the ideal way of doing things? I've used a listener and regex to basically 'disallow' entering text, and only accept numbers and decimal places. The alternative may have been declaring a class NumericalField that inherits from TextField and does that internally, but I felt that may be a bit too much for a sample?
Thanks both!

commit.message: restrict input in textfield to numerical

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+# Configure subnetwork trace
+
+Get a server-defined trace configuration for a given tier and modify its traversability scope, add new condition barriers and control what is included in the subnetwork trace result.
+
+![Configure Subnetwork Trace Sample Screenshot](ConfigureSubnetworkTrace.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+While some traces are built from an ad-hoc group of parameters, many are based on a variation of the trace configuration taken from the subnetwork definition. For example, an electrical trace will be based on the trace configuration of the subnetwork, but may add additional clauses to constrain the trace along a single phase. Similarly, a trace in a gas or electric design application may include features with a status of "In Design" that are normally excluded from trace results.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The sample loads with a server-defined trace configuration from a tier. Check or uncheck which options to include in the trace - such as containers or barriers. Use the selection boxes to define a new condition network attribute comparison. Click 'Trace' to run a subnetwork trace with this modified configuration from a default starting location.
+
+Example barrier conditions for the default dataset:
+
+* 'Transformer Load' Equal '15'
+* 'Phases Current' DoesNotIncludeTheValues 'A'
+* 'Generation KW' LessThan '50'
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create and load a `UtilityNetwork` with a feature service URL, then get an asset type and a tier by their names.
+2. Populate the choice list for the comparison source with the non-system defined `utilityNetwork.getDefinition().getNetworkAttributes()`. Populate the choice list for the comparison operator with the enum values from `UtilityAttributeComparisonOperator`.
+3. Create a `UtilityElement` from this asset type to use as the starting location for the trace.
+4. Update the selected barrier expression and the checked options in the UI using this tier's `TraceConfiguration`.

Set its `TraceConfiguration` with the modified options, selections, and expression; then run a `UtilityNetwork.traceAsync()`.
          
          
            
            8. When 'Trace' is clicked, create `UtilityTraceParameters` passing in `UtilityTraceType.SUBNETWORK` for the trace type and the default starting location. Set its `UtilityTraceConfiguration` with the modified options, selections, and expression; then run a `UtilityNetwork.traceAsync()`.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+# Configure subnetwork trace
+
+Get a server-defined trace configuration for a given tier and modify its traversability scope, add new condition barriers and control what is included in the subnetwork trace result.
+
+![Configure Subnetwork Trace Sample Screenshot](ConfigureSubnetworkTrace.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+While some traces are built from an ad-hoc group of parameters, many are based on a variation of the trace configuration taken from the subnetwork definition. For example, an electrical trace will be based on the trace configuration of the subnetwork, but may add additional clauses to constrain the trace along a single phase. Similarly, a trace in a gas or electric design application may include features with a status of "In Design" that are normally excluded from trace results.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The sample loads with a server-defined trace configuration from a tier. Check or uncheck which options to include in the trace - such as containers or barriers. Use the selection boxes to define a new condition network attribute comparison. Click 'Trace' to run a subnetwork trace with this modified configuration from a default starting location.
+
+Example barrier conditions for the default dataset:
+
+* 'Transformer Load' Equal '15'
+* 'Phases Current' DoesNotIncludeTheValues 'A'
+* 'Generation KW' LessThan '50'
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create and load a `UtilityNetwork` with a feature service URL, then get an asset type and a tier by their names.
+2. Populate the choice list for the comparison source with the non-system defined `utilityNetwork.getDefinition().getNetworkAttributes()`. Populate the choice list for the comparison operator with the enum values from `UtilityAttributeComparisonOperator`.
+3. Create a `UtilityElement` from this asset type to use as the starting location for the trace.
+4. Update the selected barrier expression and the checked options in the UI using this tier's `TraceConfiguration`.
+5. When 'Network Attribute' is selected, if its `Domain` is a `CodedValueDomain`, populate the choice list for the comparison value with its `CodedValues`.  Otherwise, display a free-form textbox for entering an attribute value.
+6. When 'Add' is clicked, create a new `UtilityNetworkAttributeComparison` using the selected comparison source, operator, and selected or typed value. Use the selected source's `UtilityNetworkAttribute.DataType` to convert the comparison value to the correct data type.
+7. If the Traversability's list of `Barriers` is not empty, create a `UtilityTraceOrCondition` with the existing `Barriers` and the new comparison from step 7.
+8. When 'Trace' is clicked, create `UtilityTraceParameters` passing in `UtilityTraceType.SUBNETWORK` for the trace type and the default starting location. Set its `TraceConfiguration` with the modified options, selections, and expression; then run a `UtilityNetwork.traceAsync()`.

nodes.bodyText: I think Utility Network now has it's own category after Jenn requested it. Probably not something for this PR, but just to make a note this is something we'll have to migrate in the future along with the other UN samples.

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
             * Copyright 2019 Esri.
          
          
            
             * Copyright 2020 Esri.
I'm a bit unsure of this comment: from the code it reads as if the expression is being set to the barriers?

it's as you've said before: this is a confusing workflow! I'm also unsure about the method description. Digging into it a little deeper, this method always returns a value. The javadoc makes it sound like a data type is returned.
Also, are there ever any booleans passed on? I couldn't find any but I admit I am totally in the dark with this sample and how it's meant to be used.
I'd be tempted to get some more experienced eyes on this just in case there's something deeper going on that we're not handling well, @tschie or @colinanderson. Should we be handling this conversion at a Java or Core level, or is this a pattern we'd expect a customer to handle?

again I'm confused by this comment. we're taking the data type, and converting it from it's type to a value, no? as the description stands, it looks like we're just retrieving if it's an integer/float etc which I think is misleading, whereas we're returning it's actual value e.g. 4?

this is cool! though I noticed when selecting e.g. "Is subnetwork controller EQUAL" and add 15.0 or 15000000000 that two exceptions are reported
java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: "15000000000"
Caused by: java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
again I'm probably not using the values a utility networker would use, and in other fields these entries seem to be ok.
I think a comment to explain this Object reference would be helpful
excess space here between param and description

to avoid repeated use of attributeComparison.getNetworkAttribute you could instead store it in a variable for re-use: up to you though, I'm ok either way.
UtilityNetworkAttribute utilityNetworkAttribute = attributeComparison.getNetworkAttribute();
unused import

nodes.bodyText:
just spotted, mixing UI with "How it Works"! Which I don't think we're meant to do, but if it must stay then we should make it obvious it's UI. Our How it works section shouldn't really have UI in them so it's not as obvious as it would be in say the "How to use section".

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            6. When 'Add' is clicked, create a new `UtilityNetworkAttributeComparison` using the selected comparison source, operator, and selected or typed value. Use the selected source's `UtilityNetworkAttribute.DataType` to convert the comparison value to the correct data type.
          
          
            
            6. When the "Add" button is clicked from the UI, create a new `UtilityNetworkAttributeComparison` using the selected comparison source, operator, and selected or typed value. Use the selected source's `UtilityNetworkAttribute.DataType` to convert the comparison value to the correct data type.

@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+# Configure subnetwork trace
+
+Get a server-defined trace configuration for a given tier and modify its traversability scope, add new condition barriers and control what is included in the subnetwork trace result.
+
+![Configure Subnetwork Trace Sample Screenshot](ConfigureSubnetworkTrace.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+While some traces are built from an ad-hoc group of parameters, many are based on a variation of the trace configuration taken from the subnetwork definition. For example, an electrical trace will be based on the trace configuration of the subnetwork, but may add additional clauses to constrain the trace along a single phase. Similarly, a trace in a gas or electric design application may include features with a status of "In Design" that are normally excluded from trace results.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The sample loads with a server-defined trace configuration from a tier. Check or uncheck which options to include in the trace - such as containers or barriers. Use the selection boxes to define a new condition network attribute comparison. Click 'Trace' to run a subnetwork trace with this modified configuration from a default starting location.
+
+Example barrier conditions for the default dataset:
+
+* 'Transformer Load' Equal '15'
+* 'Phases Current' DoesNotIncludeTheValues 'A'
+* 'Generation KW' LessThan '50'
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create and load a `UtilityNetwork` with a feature service URL, then get an asset type and a tier by their names.
+2. Populate the choice list for the comparison source with the non-system defined `utilityNetwork.getDefinition().getNetworkAttributes()`. Populate the choice list for the comparison operator with the enum values from `UtilityAttributeComparisonOperator`.
+3. Create a `UtilityElement` from this asset type to use as the starting location for the trace.
+4. Update the selected barrier expression and the checked options in the UI using this tier's `TraceConfiguration`.
+5. When 'Network Attribute' is selected, if its `Domain` is a `CodedValueDomain`, populate the choice list for the comparison value with its `CodedValues`.  Otherwise, display a free-form textbox for entering an attribute value.
+6. When 'Add' is clicked, create a new `UtilityNetworkAttributeComparison` using the selected comparison source, operator, and selected or typed value. Use the selected source's `UtilityNetworkAttribute.DataType` to convert the comparison value to the correct data type.

@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+# Configure subnetwork trace
+
+Get a server-defined trace configuration for a given tier and modify its traversability scope, add new condition barriers and control what is included in the subnetwork trace result.
+
+![Configure Subnetwork Trace Sample Screenshot](ConfigureSubnetworkTrace.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+While some traces are built from an ad-hoc group of parameters, many are based on a variation of the trace configuration taken from the subnetwork definition. For example, an electrical trace will be based on the trace configuration of the subnetwork, but may add additional clauses to constrain the trace along a single phase. Similarly, a trace in a gas or electric design application may include features with a status of "In Design" that are normally excluded from trace results.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The sample loads with a server-defined trace configuration from a tier. Check or uncheck which options to include in the trace - such as containers or barriers. Use the selection boxes to define a new condition network attribute comparison. Click 'Trace' to run a subnetwork trace with this modified configuration from a default starting location.
+
+Example barrier conditions for the default dataset:
+
+* 'Transformer Load' Equal '15'
+* 'Phases Current' DoesNotIncludeTheValues 'A'
+* 'Generation KW' LessThan '50'
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create and load a `UtilityNetwork` with a feature service URL, then get an asset type and a tier by their names.
+2. Populate the choice list for the comparison source with the non-system defined `utilityNetwork.getDefinition().getNetworkAttributes()`. Populate the choice list for the comparison operator with the enum values from `UtilityAttributeComparisonOperator`.
+3. Create a `UtilityElement` from this asset type to use as the starting location for the trace.
+4. Update the selected barrier expression and the checked options in the UI using this tier's `UtilityTraceConfiguration`.
+5. When 'Network Attribute' is selected, if its `Domain` is a `CodedValueDomain`, populate the choice list for the comparison value with its `CodedValues`.  Otherwise, display a free-form textbox for entering an attribute value.
+6. When the "Add" button is clicked from the UI, create a new `UtilityNetworkAttributeComparison` using the selected comparison source, operator, and selected or typed value. Use the selected source's `UtilityNetworkAttribute.DataType` to convert the comparison value to the correct data type.
+7. If the Traversability's list of `Barriers` is not empty, create a `UtilityTraceOrCondition` with the existing `Barriers` and the new comparison from step 7.
+8. When 'Trace' is clicked, create `UtilityTraceParameters` passing in `UtilityTraceType.SUBNETWORK` for the trace type and the default starting location. Set its `UtilityTraceConfiguration` with the modified options, selections, and expression; then run a `UtilityNetwork.traceAsync()`.
+9. When `Reset` is clicked, set the trace configurations expression back to its original value.

nodes.bodyText:
Didn't spot these button references before in here: still not 100% happy with UI references in this section but I think with UN being a complex workflow it does help to have it split up. Again we just need to ensure the button names are tagged within quotation marks rather than as code.

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            8. When 'Trace' is clicked, create `UtilityTraceParameters` passing in `UtilityTraceType.SUBNETWORK` for the trace type and the default starting location. Set its `UtilityTraceConfiguration` with the modified options, selections, and expression; then run a `UtilityNetwork.traceAsync()`.
          
          
            
            8. When the "Trace" button is clicked, create `UtilityTraceParameters` passing in `UtilityTraceType.SUBNETWORK` for the trace type and the default starting location. Set its `UtilityTraceConfiguration` with the modified options, selections, and expression; then run a `UtilityNetwork.traceAsync()`.

nodes.bodyText: Swap steps 1 and 2, to match their order in the code and also to make the reference to "this asset type" in step 3 make sense.

+
+The sample loads with a server-defined trace configuration from a tier. Check or uncheck which options to include in the trace - such as containers or barriers. Use the selection boxes to define a new condition network attribute comparison, and then use 'Add' to add it to the trace configuration. Click 'Trace' to run a subnetwork trace with this modified configuration from a default starting location.
+
+Example barrier conditions for the default dataset:
+
+* 'Transformer Load' Equal '15'
+* 'Phases Current' DoesNotIncludeTheValues 'A'
+* 'Generation KW' LessThan '50'
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create and load a `UtilityNetwork` with a feature service URL, then get an asset type and a tier by their names.
+2. Populate the choice list for the comparison source with the non-system defined `utilityNetwork.getDefinition().getNetworkAttributes()`. Populate the choice list for the comparison operator with the enum values from `UtilityAttributeComparisonOperator`.

nodes.bodyText:
There seems to be an unhelpful mixture of terminology being used here. This doc talks of 'Network Attribute' being selected, whereas the code uses the term "comparison sources", as in comparisonSourcesComboBox and onComparisonSourceChanged.
Perhaps a simple way of improving that might be to say:

When a 'Network Attribute' comparison source is selected...
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+# Configure subnetwork trace
+
+Get a server-defined trace configuration for a given tier and modify its traversability scope, add new condition barriers and control what is included in the subnetwork trace result.
+
+![Image of configure subnetwork trace](ConfigureSubnetworkTrace.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+While some traces are built from an ad-hoc group of parameters, many are based on a variation of the trace configuration taken from the subnetwork definition. For example, an electrical trace will be based on the trace configuration of the subnetwork, but may add additional clauses to constrain the trace along a single phase. Similarly, a trace in a gas or electric design application may include features with a status of "In Design" that are normally excluded from trace results.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The sample loads with a server-defined trace configuration from a tier. Check or uncheck which options to include in the trace - such as containers or barriers. Use the selection boxes to define a new condition network attribute comparison, and then use 'Add' to add it to the trace configuration. Click 'Trace' to run a subnetwork trace with this modified configuration from a default starting location.
+
+Example barrier conditions for the default dataset:
+
+* 'Transformer Load' Equal '15'
+* 'Phases Current' DoesNotIncludeTheValues 'A'
+* 'Generation KW' LessThan '50'
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create and load a `UtilityNetwork` with a feature service URL, then get an asset type and a tier by their names.
+2. Populate the choice list for the comparison source with the non-system defined `utilityNetwork.getDefinition().getNetworkAttributes()`. Populate the choice list for the comparison operator with the enum values from `UtilityAttributeComparisonOperator`.
+3. Create a `UtilityElement` from this asset type to use as the starting location for the trace.
+4. Update the selected barrier expression and the checked options in the UI using this tier's `UtilityTraceConfiguration`.
+5. When 'Network Attribute' is selected, if its `Domain` is a `CodedValueDomain`, populate the choice list for the comparison value with its `CodedValue`s. Otherwise, display a free-form textbox for entering an attribute value.

nodes.bodyText:
I'd swap steps 9 and 10, because 10 relates to the trace that's run in step 8.
Also: the count elements -> the count of elements
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+# Configure subnetwork trace
+
+Get a server-defined trace configuration for a given tier and modify its traversability scope, add new condition barriers and control what is included in the subnetwork trace result.
+
+![Image of configure subnetwork trace](ConfigureSubnetworkTrace.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+While some traces are built from an ad-hoc group of parameters, many are based on a variation of the trace configuration taken from the subnetwork definition. For example, an electrical trace will be based on the trace configuration of the subnetwork, but may add additional clauses to constrain the trace along a single phase. Similarly, a trace in a gas or electric design application may include features with a status of "In Design" that are normally excluded from trace results.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The sample loads with a server-defined trace configuration from a tier. Check or uncheck which options to include in the trace - such as containers or barriers. Use the selection boxes to define a new condition network attribute comparison, and then use 'Add' to add it to the trace configuration. Click 'Trace' to run a subnetwork trace with this modified configuration from a default starting location.
+
+Example barrier conditions for the default dataset:
+
+* 'Transformer Load' Equal '15'
+* 'Phases Current' DoesNotIncludeTheValues 'A'
+* 'Generation KW' LessThan '50'
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create and load a `UtilityNetwork` with a feature service URL, then get an asset type and a tier by their names.
+2. Populate the choice list for the comparison source with the non-system defined `utilityNetwork.getDefinition().getNetworkAttributes()`. Populate the choice list for the comparison operator with the enum values from `UtilityAttributeComparisonOperator`.
+3. Create a `UtilityElement` from this asset type to use as the starting location for the trace.
+4. Update the selected barrier expression and the checked options in the UI using this tier's `UtilityTraceConfiguration`.
+5. When 'Network Attribute' is selected, if its `Domain` is a `CodedValueDomain`, populate the choice list for the comparison value with its `CodedValue`s. Otherwise, display a free-form textbox for entering an attribute value.
+6. When the 'Add' button is clicked from the UI, create a new `UtilityNetworkAttributeComparison` using the selected comparison source, operator, and selected or typed value. Use the selected source's `UtilityNetworkAttribute.DataType` to convert the comparison value to the correct data type.
+7. If the Traversability's list of `Barriers` is not empty, create a `UtilityTraceOrCondition` with the existing `Barriers` and the new comparison from step 7.
+8. When the 'Trace' button is clicked, create `UtilityTraceParameters` passing in `UtilityTraceType.SUBNETWORK` for the trace type and the default starting location. Set its `UtilityTraceConfiguration` with the modified options, selections, and expression; then run a `UtilityNetwork.traceAsync()`.
+9. When the 'Reset' button is clicked, set the trace configurations expression back to its original value.
+10. Display the count elements returned within the `UtilityElementTraceResult`.

nodes.bodyText: Unused import

Extra comments about how we handle the Domain types might help. For example, here we could say something like:

For CodedValueDomains, add the name of a CodedValue that matches the network attribute's comparison value (if any)

and below, at the start of the associated else block, something like:

For other types of domain, add the name of the "other" attribute in the comparison, or the value in the comparison if there's no "other" attribute
